answers.answer: Hi there!It is great to hear about your mom and I really wish that we all had the same determination to continue in life despite the hardships. Diabetes per say is not a disease but just a deficiency of either insulin or its action and we should consider ourselves fortunate to have lived at a time when it can be well managed and appreciate the life God has given us. All humans have a tendency to sympathize themselves without realizing that there are worse things in life and there are people who struggle just to survive.Anyhow wish her a healthy and beautiful life!Take care!

I'm guessing your mom was around 30 or so when diagnosed? I am a type 1 and have had it for 12 years now. I am 20. Besides myself my youngest sister and older brother also have it. I understand that there are people who wonder why not take care of yourself? For me I have both the determination as well as the set backs that come along with it. In march I became pregnant and have always thought my chances were slim. I miscarried in april and ended up in critical care because of ketones. I was devistated even though my a1c dropped from an 8.9 to 7.8 in 3 months. Other then the fact of Having problems with concieving I also have to worry about making enough money to support the cost of diabetes. The stress of working hard makes the thought of living unbearable and even though I want to live and want to take care of myself I don't. Its great to hear about your mom but since she has been diagnosed if I'm correct has probably had so much motivation to keep living because of maybe children or a husband. And sometimes people have a hard time taking care of it for many reasons. Hopefully I will end up like your mom living to see my 94th birthday with great control of my diabetes. However like I said the decisions people make have so many different factors.

question: Why can't we have the desire to live and maintain our health like the "Greatest Generation" has done.  My Mom will be 94 the 1st day of September.  She does not, nor has she ever strayed from her maintenance plan.  Mom has been on insulin for away over 60 years and today has an insulin pump.  She is type 1.  Her feet are precious, soft as a baby's bottom...we are very careful when pedicures are taking place.  Mother has 3 meals per day and 2 snacks sometimes 3 if her BS is low prior to bedtime.  There has been nothing easy about her life but she keeps on keeping on.  In February she broke her hip and had surgery to repair, hemmorging occured and they had to go back in plus give her 5 pints of blood.  I plan to write a book on her someday because God has given her more determination and spunk than anyone I know................
title: Why do people simply refuse to take proper can with diabetes?
